Conference of the Working Group on Museums of the German Anthropological Association and the Museum Fünf Kontinente, Munich, April 2017; Larissa Förster: Problematic Provenances: Museum and university collections from a post-colonial perspective, in: German Colonialism, p. 154–61; Stoecker, Schnalke, and Winkelmann, Sammeln, Erforschen, Zurückgeben?. [37] Examplary: Gitte Beckmann (ed.): “Man eben Alles sammeln”: Der Zürcher Botaniker Forschungsreisende Hans Schinz ethnographische Sammlung Südwestafrika, Zurich: Verlag Neue Zürcher Zeitung, 2012.

========== Fossils return agenda gathering momentum EDWARD QORRO Arusha 20/02/2019 0 Comments THE Federal Republic of Germany is currently engaging Tanzania finalising the restitution of the Tendaguru dinosaur fossils that are currently preserved at a museum Berlin. The two countries have recently been deep discussions, exploring ways of returning the dinosaur remains that are kept at the Natural History Museum of Berlin. Responding to questions posed to him by ‘Daily News’ on Monday evening, German Ambassador to Tanzania Dr Detlef Waechter said experts from both countries have constantly been discussing ways of returning the fossils back to Tanzania. Dr Waechter, who speaking shortly before seeing off the country’s delegation to Berlin for the International Tourism Fair Berlin (ITB) slated for next month, maintained that Tanzania had a legitimate right to own and being possession of its relics, but it still up to the experts to decide on how and when the relic should be returned. “We don’t want to shy away from these discussions, our aim is to eventually see the fossils transferred to Tanzania,” explained the diplomat. The German Ambassador stressed that his country willing to help Tanzania hosting the dinosaur the country. “I have been constant discussions with the country’s head of museums on how best we can realise the restitution,” he said. The bones of the large Sauropod, known as Janenschia, were among the first fossils found during the Tendaguru expedition. Although only the remains of the legs and two vertebrae belonging to two different animals were found during the expedition, the animal is said to be a fascination to scientists working the state-of-the-art museum, according to available literature about the fossils. Last year, the government revealed that it working on plans to construct a museum Tendaguru village Lindi Region, where the fossils be preserved. The Tendaguru Beds as a fossil deposit were first discovered 1906, when German pharmacist, chemical analyst and mining engineer Bernhard Wilhelm Sattler, on his way to a mine south of the Mbemkure River German East Africa (today Tanzania), noticed enormous bones weathering out of the path near the base of a hill. Because of its morphology, the hill locally known as steep hill Tendaguru the language of the local Wamwera people. The Permanent Secretary the Ministry of Natural Resources and Tourism, Prof Adolf Mkenda, welcomed Germany’s move of supporting Tanzania the cause. “There is urgent need of investing museums where our artifacts can be preserved,” explained the PS. He further disclosed that 50 per cent of the proceeds from the Olduvai Gorge’s museum Ngorongoro Conservation Area (NCA) be channelled towards upgrading of museums the country. The Tanzanian delegation for Berlin which comprises 160 people drawn from the tourism and the hospitality sector, is set to leave the country early next month for the massive tourism expo which stretched from March 6 to March 10. Tanzania be participating the exhibition for the 53rd time since its inception. The expo is the furthermost business platform for global touristic offers where more than 10,000 exhibitors from 180 countries be present and over 160,000 visitors are expected to visit the ITB. title: (PDF) Photogrammetric survey of dinosaur skeletons
text: Mitt Mus Nat .kd Berl Geowiss Reihe 2 (1999) 113-119 19.10 .1999 Photogrammetric Survey of Dinosaur Skeletons Albert Wiedemann', Tim Suthau l Jörg Albertz With 9 figures Abstract To derive physiological data of dinosaurs, it is necessary to determine the volume and the surface area of this animals For this purpose, a detailed survey of reconstructed skeletons is required The skeletons of three dinosaurs the Museum ftir Naturkunde Berlin and two skeletons the Museum d'Histoire Naturelle Paris have been surveyed using stereo photo- grammetry Two of the Berlin skeletons were surveyed with the close range laser scanners of the Institut Navigation of the Universität Stuttgart Both data acquisition techniques require a geodetic control network as a geometric reference system The surveying methods used, together with results of mathematical approaches for the determination of the volume and surface of the animals are presented this paper Key words Dinosaur skeletons, survey, photogrammetry, laser scanner Zusammenfassung Zur Herleitung physiologischer Daten Dinosaurier erforderlich, zunächst Volumen Oberfläche Körpers bestimmen Dazu wurde detaillierte Vermessung rekonstruierter Skelette durchgeführt Die Skelette dreier Saurier Museum Naturkunde Berlin zweier Museum d'Histoire Naturelle Paris wurden stereophotogrammetrisch vermessen Bei zwei Berliner Skelette wurden zusätzlich Laserscanner Instituts Navigation Universität Stuttgart eingesetzt Beide Datenerfassungstechniken benötigen Paßpunktfeld geometrisches Referenzsystem Die ver- wendeten Vermessungsmethoden, mathematischen Ansätze Berechnung Volumina Oberflächen Ergebnisse Aufsatz vorgestellt Schlüsselwörter Dinosaurierskelette, Vermessung, Photogrammetrie, Laserscanner Objective In order to collect data on the paleobiology of dinosaurs, the skeletons mustbe examined de- tail Considerable physiological data can be ac- quired, using characteristics of extant animals and methods of comparative physiology based on the body volume and the body surface area This data can employ mathematical models, if precise data about the skeletons is available The Institut Physiologie Freien Uni- versitdt Berlin requested the Fachgebiet ftir Photogrammetrie and Kartographie Techni- schen Universit5t Berlin to carry out a measure- ment of the skeleton of Brachiosaurus brancai the Museum Naturkunde Humboldt- Universitdt Berlin Photogrammetry is a detailed and precise surveying technique which allows the collection of a large amount of data during a short campaign with no contact to the object The skeleton of Brachiosaurus brancai is the largest museum mounted dinosaur skeleton the world It discovered at the beginning of the century Tendaguru, at that time German East Africa, today Tanzania Later it build up Berlin 1937 (Christian Heinrich 1998) The mounted skeleton is a composite Missing parts are substituted by either elements of skele- tons of approximately the same size (e .g tail) or by plaster reconstructions (e .g right shoulder blade) Some of the preserved skeletal elements have been replaced by plaster reconstruc- tions (e .g cervical and dorsal vertebrae) owing to their fragility (for details see Christian Heinrich 1998) The measurement accom- plished 1993/94 with conventional stereo-photo- grammetric methods Technische Universität Berlin, Fachgebiet Photogrammetrie Kartographie, Straße 17 Juni 135, Sekr E139, 10623 Berlin, Germany Received March 1999, accepted June 1999 Table 1 Overview on the Surveyed Dinosaur Skeletons After experience developed through the measurement of Brachiosaurus the skeletons of two further sauropods were tackled the Museum Naturkunde Berlin 1996/97 Diplodocus carnegii and Dicraeosaurus hanse- manni Dicraeosaurus originates from Tenda- guru The head is a cast Diplodocus is repre- sented by a complete cast ofthe skeleton from the USA As its original has been stored dark rock, even the copy accordingly dark, while both other Dinosaur skeletons are clearly brighter In the case of this two skeletons addition to the photogrammetric approach, the two laser scan- ners of the Institut Navigation of the Univer- sitdt Stuttgart were used (Wiedemann Wehr 1997) In spring 1998 two further dinosaur skeletons were surveyed the Museum d'Histoire Natu- relle Paris, France Iguanodon bernissartensis and Allosaurus fragilis Here only stereo photo- grammetry used, based on the experiences of the former campaigns In the Table 1 the most important data of the dinosaur skeletons, the photographs and the results are summarized Geodetic measurements Both for photogrammetric and laser scanner work a network of geodetic surveyed control points is necessary About 10-20 control points have been Wiedemann, A T Suthau J Albertz, Photogrammetric Survey of Dinosaur Skeletons Brachiosaurus Diplodocus brancai carnegii Dicraeosaurus Iguanodon Allosaurus hansemanni bernissartensis fragilis signalized at and around each skeleton using polystyrene balls of about 20 mm diameter The survey has been done using a Sokkia total sta- tion and automatic data registration and data flow to the network adjustment software First a polygon measured to determine the location of the instrument stations by mea- suring angles and distances with the theodolite system and the electronic distance measurement system the total station Then each control point has to be measuredfrom at least two dif- ferent stations to allow the calculation of the points by ray intersection These points were measured sides with accuracy of ±10-20 mm The geodetic measurement of the required con- trol points lasts a few hours, depending on the circumstances Measurements a cramped en- vironment are problematic, because other ob- jects may obstruct important views Further tie points the form of glued on pa- per marks of about 5 mm diameter were at- tached to the skeletons and the background These were not geodetic measured, but can be clearly identified and precisely measured the metric images Photogrammetric measurements The dinosaur skeletons consist of many indi- vidual bones, whose position and form must be Horizontal Length Height Control Points 18 m 12 m 20 23 m 4 m 29 13m 3m 17 8m 4m 13 8m 3m 13 Stereophotogr Surveyed Sides 2 1 1 1 1 Image Scale ca 1 :200 ca 1 :100 ca 1 :100 ca 1 :100 ca 1 :100 Bases 2 3 1 1 1 Polygons 572 993 322 298 280 Points on the Object 6518 15059 8367 2817 5190 Laserscanner Data Sets 21 8 Points 861021 589824 Results Segments 50 75 50 64 55 Volume 74,4 m 3 32,4 m 3 12,8 m3 8,4 m3 3,3 m3 Surface 140 m 2 93,4 m 2 46,4 m2 36,1 m2 21,2 m2 Mitt Mus Nat .kd Berl Geowiss Reihe 2 (1999) Fig 1 Principle of stereophotogrammetry determined Because of the absence of clearly identifiable points only a stereo photogram- metric measurement applicable The stereo photogrammetric approach is based on the use of two images, acquired from two different loca- tions The line between these two projection cen- ters (O', O") is called base The viewing direc- tions should be parallel and perpendicular to the base (Fig 1) This image arrangement is compar- able to the arrangement of our eyes If each im- age is arranged to other eye, we are able to see a 3D model This is used analytical stereo photogrammetric instrument, such as the Kern DSRll at the Technical University of Ber- lin (Fig 2) In such instrument a 3D measure- mentmark can be moved three dimensions and the movement can be stored to build up a 3D CAD wire model Fig 2 Analytical Instrument Kern DSR11 Fig 3 Metric image of Brachiosaurus brancai The Brachiosaurus skeleton is located the center of the main hall of the Museum Naturkunde and imaged from both sides The photographs were acquired from the gallery with the terrestrial metric camera Zeiss TMK 6 (Fig 3) The selected base-to-distance relation- ship of approx 1 :1 led to very large parallaxes, which proved problematic during the restitution The stereoscopic view very difficult to inter- pret, since the skeleton has no closed surface but intersecting rays had to be evaluated The fusion of the two models permitted the development of one CAD wire model (Fig 4), consisting of the outlines of the, edges of the bones lateral view For this reason, the evi- dence of the bone outlines other views is lim- ited A parallel projection of the data set into one vertical plane along the longitudinal axis of the skeleton used to form a diagram of the Fig 4 Restitution result of Brachiosaurus brancai three views _ __ _ _ _ Fig 5 Result of the stereophotogrammetric restitution Wiedemann, A T Suthau J Albertz, Photogrammetric Survey of Dinosaur Skeletons 024 skeleton (Fig 5) From this physiologists were able to derive considerable data (Gunga et al 1995) Due to the length of the specimen we had to acquire Diplodocus carnegii three photogram- metric models Dicraeosaurus hansemanni acquired only one photogrammetric model, ignoring the last 4 meters of the tail Both skele- tons can be accessed only from one side During this second photograph campaign the back- ground of glass proved as disturbing for optimal lighting conditions for the photogrammetric pic- ture recording Reflections made a balanced illumination more difficult In particular on the darker Diplodocus skeleton it difficult to de- tect the structures on the bones on the photo- graphic material Nevertheless more details could be captured due to the larger image scale and the more suitable base-to-distance relation- ship compared to the measurements at Brachio- saurus Based on the experiences Berlin some ac- celerated and improved techniques have been used during the measurement campaign Paris The windows and showcases the Museum d'Histoire Naturelle around the skeletons have been covered using paper and blankets A prob- 6m Laser scanner lem the build up of the skeletons, which are very close to other objects For backup reasons we acquired a few stereo pairs, but only one pair per object required to survey most of the skeletons To support the photogrammetric data acquisition and to evaluate new technologies the two smal- ler dinosaur skeletons Berlin were sur- veyed with the two laser scanners (Fig 6) of the Institut Navigation Universität Stuttgart (INS) With this system a laser beam is directed over a room segment by two rotating mirrors to scan the surfaces Apart from the intensity of the reflected signal the phase of two measurement signals is recorded From these phase meas- urements the distance between the system and the reflecting surface can be derived The two skew angles and the object distance define a set of polar coordinates for the object points The intensity of the reflected signal supplies addi- tional information Distances and intensity are stored raster files, the vertical skew angle de- Mitt Mus Nat .kd Berl Geowiss Reihe 2 (1999) Fig 6 Laser scanner fines the lines and the horizontal skew angles represent the columns From these polar coordi- nates cartesian coordinates a local system can be computed with simple formulas (Wehr 1997) The survey of the skeletons took place seg- ments of 400 x 400 points with a field of view of approximately 30° x 30° azimuth and eleva- tion The range limited to a few meters, de- pending on the reflectance of the objects surface The control points signals could be identified the distance image and the intensity image, signalized tie points only the intensity image With the help of the geodetic control points the individual spatial point clouds were transformed into the common coordinate system of the geo- detic network Fig 7 Data of Dicraeosaurus composed from 8 data sets showing intensity (upper) and distance (lower) images As with the photogrammetric image acquisi- tion, the glass background proved problematic The laser signal reflected by the glass, or bent or passed through and reflected from the neighbor room Apart from other interferences this led to measurements greater than 10 m, which resulted ambiguities In order to pre- vent this, we covered the glass plates with paper or linen sheets Whereas the data acquisition at Dicraeosaurus required eight data sets, 21 data sets were neces- sary to scan Diplodocus After the measurement, the data sets were filtered and merged to one data set for each of the two skeletons From this data sets, the depth map and parallel projections can be deduced (Fig 7) The gap the tail of Dicraeosaurus results from area occluded by a showcase The intensity of the reflected signal is a func- tion of the reflection characteristics of the ob- jects surface, the wavelength of the carrier wave and the exposition of the surface relation to incident light For example the darker head of Dicraeosaurus (Fig 7), the gypsum reflects the carrier wave of the measuring signal less effec- tive than the petrified bones of the neck Dark surfaces reflect more poorly than light surfaces The combination of these two reflection charac- teristics caused problems with Diplodocus A suf- ficient signal could only be achieved using a shorter distance, that more data sets were ne- cessary than planned Owing to the high albedo of the dust on the skeleton it could nevertheless Fig 8 Stereophotogrammetric restitution superimposed on the intensity image be measured Figure 8 shows the superimposi- tion of a stereophotogrammetric restitution re- sult upon the intensity image of the laser scan- ner Results and interpretation The results of all stereophotogrammetric restitu- tions are shown Fig 9 at the same scale to give indication of the relative size of the dif- ferent skeletons The next step to deduce the body forms of the dinosaurs For this pur- pose a flesh layer, reconstructed by the physiolo- gists added to the wire model of the skele- ton, and three-dimensional geometric primitives have been selected to adjust the form of the 3D Wiedemann, A T Suthau J Albertz, Photogrammetric Survey of Dinosaur Skeletons model Most of them were truncated cones and spherical caps Thus a barrel form resulted for example for the torax With the help of these primitives the volume and the surface of the dinosaur were computed New calculations based on numerical integra- tion of the cross section area through the CAD model of Brachiosaurus brancai resulted overall volume estimation of 15-20 m 3 less than the recent calculations The results serve palaeo-physiologists as ini- tial values for the determination of a multiplicity of further physiological data A lot of them can be found the paper of Gunga et al (1999) the same volume The evaluation of the results must consider the following possible sources of error Fig 9 Comparison between Brachiosaurus (upper left), Diplodocus (lower left), Dicraeosaurus (upper right), Iguanodon (middle right) and Allosaurus (lower right) showing their skeletons the same scale Mitt Mus Nat .kd Berl Geowiss Reihe 2 (1999) 0 Incorrect construction of the skeleton Such error influences can be avoided only by a careful preparation of the skeleton and a scientifically based reconstruction The struc- ture of the skeletons Berlin is considered as scientifically based Inaccurate measurement The adjustment of the geodetic measurement resulted mean errors of 10-20 mm With image scale of approx 1 :100 to 1 :200 the expected photo- grammetric inaccuracies are within the range of a few millimeters These are usually more exact than the point definition on the skele- ton 0 Estimation of the flesh layer The thickness of the flesh layer varies the food supply and must therefore have varied considerably While the influence of this on the surface can be ne- glected, it is substantial for the computation of volumes In particular the lower belly area, where no bones are present the shape is un- certain 0 The mathematical model used for the calcula- tion of surface and volume The use of a circu- lar cross sections appears somewhat question- able the region of the thorax In particular if one views the skeleton of Brachiosaurus from above and from the side, one recognizes that the trunk is clearly higher than broad (Fig 4) This is problematic particularly because of the enormous portion that the trunk contri- butes to the total volume of the dinosaurs Conclusions The photogrammetric work consists of two main phases first preparation, measurement of con- trol information and image acquisition This has to be done during the campaign and lasts about one or two days per skeleton This is fast con- sideration to the enormous amount of data ac- quired The second phase is much more time consuming and consists of the adjustment of the geodetic measurements, the development and orientation of the images and the tedious restitu- tion work with the stereo photogrammetric in- strument The required time for this work lasts weeks, but can be carried out independently from the campaign at any time at home It has been shown already that the results of the work with the laser scanner were more quickly available than the results of the photo- grammetric evaluation However the techniques Acknowledgements References mustbe further improved for the elimination of incorrect measurements from the point clouds of the laser scanners In particular at the edges of the bones a wrong distance computed as weighted mean value of foreground (bone) and background The main drawback of the laser scanner system is the limited range, which re- quired the data acquisition a lot of individual data sets, what is very time consuming This change the near future with a further develop- ment of the system The work of the project "Dinosaurier Lagerstätte Tendagu- ru" is supported by the Deutsche Forschungs- Gemeinschaft (DFG) We thank PD Dr med Dipl .-Geol Hanns-Christia n Gunga and Professor Dr med Karl A Kirsch, from the In- stitut Physiologie Freien Universität Berlin, for the initiation of this project and the support of our work Fur- ther thanks to the staff of the Museum Naturkunde Humboldt-Universität Berlin, especially Dr Wolf-Dieter Heinrich and Prof Hans-Peter Schultze, who gave us access to the skeletons and supported us every possible manner Further we want to thank the following persons at the Fach- gebiet Photogrammetrie Kartographie Technischen Univerisität Berlin Klaus Witt for the qualified support with all photographic works and students Wolfram Lisowski and Sascha Mokry for the tedious stereo-evaluations and post processing Many thanks to Dr .-Ing Aloys Wehr and Dipl Ing (FH) Martin Thomas of the Institut Navigation Universität Stuttgart for the data acquisition and preparation of the laser scanner data Christian, A Heinrich, W .-D 1998 The neck posture of Brachiosaurus brancai Mitteilungen Museum Naturkunde Berlin, Geowissenschaftliche Reihe l 73-80 Gunga, H .-Chr Kirsch, K A Baartz, E, ROcker, L Hein- rich, W .-D Lisowski, W Wiedemann, A Albertz, J 1995 New Data on the Dimensions of Brachiosaurus brancai and their Physiological Implications Naturwis- senschaften 82 190-192 Gunga, H .-Chr Kirsch, K A Rittweger, J Clarke, A Al- bertz, J, Wiedemann, A Mokry, S Suthau, T Wehr, A Heinrich, W .-D Schultze, H .-P 1999 Body size and body volume distribution two sauropods from the Up- per Jurassic of Tendaguru/Tanzania/East Africa Mit- teilungen Museum Naturkunde Berlin, Geowissenschaftliche Reihe 2 91-102 Wehr, A 1997 Abbildende Laserscanner Anwendungen Bauaufnahme Denkmalpflege In Albertz, J Wiedemann, A (eds Architekturphotogrammetrie ge- stern heute morgen Technische Universität Berlin 1997 114-127 Wiedemann, A Wehr, A 1998 Vermessung Dino- saurierskeletten Stereophotogrammetrie Laser- scanner In List, E K (ed Photogrammetrie Wandel, Lehre Forschung - Anwendung Proceedings of the Annual Meeting of the Deutsche Gesellschaft Photo- grammetrie Fernerkundung (DGPF), 1997 Frank- furt/Main, Band 6 301-308, Berlin

title: A little history of the Tendaguru Expedition - Dinosaur Toy Blog
text: A little history of the Tendaguru Expedition Welcome, Guest . Please login or register . 1 Hour 1 Day 1 Week 1 Month Forever Login with username, password and session length News: What are your favourite prehistoric animal toys of last year? Vote now our poll ! Home Help Rules Recent Search Calendar DinoToyBlog Links Animal Toy Forum Dinosaur Toy Forum version 1 archive STS Forum Animal Toy Blog Login Register Dinosaur Toy Forum » Forum » Dinosaurs and palaeontology » In the news » A little history of the Tendaguru Expedition dinotoyforum-banner tpcontentHeader « previous next » Print Pages: [ 1 ] Go Down Author Topic: A little history of the Tendaguru Expedition (Read 694 times) Lanthanotus Reviewer Carboniferous survivor Posts: 2105 A little history of the Tendaguru Expedition « on: January 07, 2021, 05:38:10 PM » A short introduction to the history of the wolrd famous Tendaguru expedition (~1907) English translation of the text thanks to Google: The Tendaguru expedition is still considered one of the most successful paleontological excavations today. The Tendaguru hill, which countless dinosaur fossils were hidden, is located Tanzania eastern Africa. Between 1885 and 1918 the area belonged to the German East Africa colony and under the rule of the German Emperor as a "protected area". How did it come about that dinosaurs were dug there and their bones ended up Berlin? This story can be read detail the book by Ina Heumann and her colleagues, which published under the title »Dinosaur Fragments«. Initially, the colonial administration had sold licenses to various companies order to open up the area for the German Empire. In 1904, a five-year concession granted to the Lindi mining company, which committed itself to investing at least 10,000 marks annually mining for minerals. The company named after Lindi, a port town about 60 kilometers from Tendaguru. After just a few years, however, the company on the verge of collapse. And that has to do with one of the most violent chapters German colonial history. In 1905 a colonial broke out German East Africa, the Maji Maji War. The African population had united uprising against the German occupiers. The colonial troops acted extremely brutally against the resistance movement. The consequences of the were devastating. Historians assume that about a third of the population died as a result of acts of war, hunger and the deliberate destruction of crops and seeds. 225 tons of fossils are shipped to Berlin The equipment of the Lindi mining company destroyed the war. In addition, the company had not made a profit since acquiring the license. Nevertheless, they continued to dig as not to lose the concession. One day 1907 African worker reported to the manager that huge bones had been found. The company informed the colonial administration the German Reich, which reacted cautiously. It definitely only giraffe or elephant bones, the tenor of the answer. Nevertheless, the authority sent the paleontologist Eberhard Fraas (18621915) to be on the safe side. He should take a look at the finds. The way to the Tendaguru somewhat arduous. From Lindi it took four to six days on foot to get there on unpaved roads. Fraas stayed a week because it immediately clear to him that this not ordinary site, but that the remains of enormous dinosaurs lay before him. The colonial administration, however, continued to show disinterest. A state-funded expedition is out of the question. So Wilhelm Branca (18441928) got involved. He director of the Geological-Paleontological Institute and Museum Berlin - he organized excavation. To raise the money, Branca founded the Tendaguru Committee. Enough people answered his appeals for donations for expedition to begin. How did the fossils get to Berlin? In the end, the excavation took four years, to extent that has seldom been seen before paleontological projects: up to 500 workers, most of them from the African population, uncovered the fossils. In days of marches, they carried a total of 225 tons of bones 800 transport boxes to the port, from where they were then shipped to Berlin. Unopened boxes from the Tendaguru expedition are still stored the Museum of Natural History. But how it even possible that the German researchers were allowed to transfer the fossils to Berlin? According to the legal situation at the time, the land at Tendaguru belonged to the German Empire. But only because the Germans had declared themselves the owners! In 1908 the colonial administration declared the country to be "ownerless" and annexed it as crown land. "Such crown land declarations were made the course of the economic development of the colony and fact represented expropriation and expulsion of the local population," says the Berlin Museum of Natural History. The German Reich had therefore acquired the land - and the fossils it contained - anything but lawful. The most spectacular dinosaur finds came to light the 19th and early 20th centuries, especially the United States. One of the most famous and largest skeletons the Diplodocus carnegii discovered Pittsburgh, named after the millionaire Andrew Carnegie. He sent casts of the Diplodocus to many museums Europe, which is why the skeleton could be admired Paris, Vienna, Bologna, Madrid and, since 1908, Berlin. The largest assembled dinosaur skeleton the world But the finds at Tendaguru exceeded everything that known until then. However, a few years passed before the first dinosaur exhibited Berlin. It wasn't until 1924 that the time had come: a Kentrosaurus, a pelvic dinosaur from the stegosauria group, built the atrium of the Museum Naturkunde. Today's highlight of the exhibition added 1937: the Brachiosaurus brancai. The taxidermists had put together the skeleton with enormous effort; they needed 450 hours of work for just one cervical vertebra. The dinosaur named after the museum director at the time, Wilhelm Branca. Brachiosaurus brancai is still the largest assembled dinosaur skeleton the world at a height of 13.27 meters. It lived 150 million years ago and weighed around 50 tons. With a total length of around 26 meters, it one of the largest land animals the history of the earth. In 2009 it turned out that the genre wrong. It wasn't a Brachiosaurus at all, but a Giraffatitan. A trip to Japan saves the dinosaurs The large dinosaur skeletons of the Tendaguru expedition began a special journey 1984: packed 92 transport boxes, they were shipped from the port of Hamburg to Tokyo, where they were on display for 100 days exhibition. For this, Giraffatitan brancai had to be dismantled and prepared with Paraloid, age-resistant plastic. This work likely saved the skeleton. In the meantime it badly weathered that it would have collapsed at some point. The colonial context from which the Tendaguru dinosaurs came faded into the background over the years. For a long time it not included the exhibition. For several years, however, the museum has been trying to come to terms with it. For example, researchers working with Ina Heumann reconstructed the colonial history of the skeletons over a period of three years and 2018 brought out a comprehensive publication. Much of the events of that time were made known. In addition, there has been a memorandum of understanding with the University of Dar Salaam since 2019, with which both institutions want to promote their cooperation. Restitution, as is currently being discussed for the Benin bronzes the newly opened Humboldt Forum, is hardly issue at the moment. A return has been a long way off since 2011: Berlin has registered the Giraffatitan brancai the register of nationally protected cultural assets. Thus, according to the Culture Protection Act, remaining the federal territory is the outstanding cultural public interest. Note d. Red .: This article is based on the research results that the historian Ina Heumann and her team from the Museum Naturkunde Berlin published the following book 2018: Ina Heumann, Holger Stoecker, Marco Tamborini, Mareike Vennen, »Dinosaur Fragments. On the history of the Tendaguru expedition and its objects, 1906-2018 «(2018). title: Countries demand their fossils back, forcing natural history ...
text: Countries demand their fossils back, forcing natural history museums to confront their past BERLIN—Step into the main hall of the Natural History Museum here and you'll be greeted by a towering dinosaur skeleton, the tallest ever mounted. Nearly four stories high and twice as long as a school bus, the sauropod Giraffatitan brancai the largest dinosaur known for more than a half-century. It has been a crowd magnet since it first displayed 1937. But the tidal flats Giraffatitan bestrode 150 million years ago weren't Europe. It lived eastern Africa, today's Tanzania, much of which a German colony when the fossil unearthed the early 1900s. Now, some Tanzanian politicians argue the fossils should return to Africa. Berlin's Natural History Museum isn't the only one facing calls for the return of fossils, which echo repatriation demands for human remains and cultural artifacts. Many specimens were collected under conditions considered unethical today, such as brutal colonial rule that ignored the ownership rights and knowledge of indigenous people. "Natural history museums as we know them wouldn't exist without the colonial period," says Holger Stoecker, African studies expert at Humboldt University here. He says repatriation requests are prompting new questions about the stories of "discovery" that many museums have traditionally told. The discussion "is escalating right now," and highlights that natural history isn't "apolitical and neutral," says Ciraj Rassool, a historian and museum studies expert at the University of the Western Cape Cape Town, South Africa. Although German paleontologists have traditionally gotten credit for discovering Giraffatitan, it fact local residents, who knew the bones and used them religious rites, who guided the foreigners to the find, Stoecker says. He part of a 3-year project to document the history of the "Tendaguru expedition" that shipped 225 tons of fossils to Berlin between 1909 and 1913. The project reveals how local residents' contributions were erased. For example, expedition documents call another dinosaur "Nyrorosaurus" after Seliman Nyororo, a local who led the 1909 excavation of the skeleton. That dinosaur is now on display here, but is named Dicraeosaurus sattleri after a German mining engineer. The Natural History Museum London is now facing at least three repatriation requests for prominent specimens: Gibraltar has asked for two Neanderthal skulls; Chile has requested exquisitely preserved skin, fur, and bones from a 12,000-year-old giant ground sloth (Mylodon darwinii); and Zambia has asked for the Broken Hill skull, a famous early hominin about 300,000 years old that's usually classified as Homo heidelbergensis. Many of these objects were sent to Europe without much thought given to who might own them. The first Neanderthal discovered, for example, unearthed 1848 by a British lieutenant stationed what then the U.K. military base of Gibraltar. Some 70 years later, British archaeologist Dorothy Garrod found a Neanderthal child's skull a Gibraltar cave and sent it to England for study. At the time, Gibraltar lacked facilities to house the bones, says Clive Finlayson, a paleontologist and director of the Gibraltar Museum. Today, Gibraltar is still formally part of the United Kingdom, but it has significant autonomy and its own government. It's home to several Neanderthal experts, and part of the territory has been named a World Heritage Site because of its rich evidence of Neanderthals. "These individuals should return home," Finlayson says of the skulls. "They were discovered here. They were humans who were living here and died here." The London Natural History Museum declined to comment on any ongoing cases, saying only that it makes its collections available "through tens of thousands of items loaned each year, hosting thousands of scientific visitors to use the collections" and via online data repositories. Negotiations are ongoing, Finlayson says. "I remain optimistic." Chile is making a similar claim for the Mylodon remains. European explorers found them the 1890s and shipped them home without permission from local authorities. They have ended up distributed among half a dozen museums Europe. Chile retains a few smaller Mylodon bones and dung, but the spectacularly preserved skin specimens are a key part of its natural heritage, says David Rubilar-Rogers, director of paleontology at the National Museum of Natural History Santiago. The Chilean museum has successfully retrieved other fossils, Rubilar-Rogers notes. In 2008, the Senckenberg Museum Frankfurt, Germany, helped Chile repatriate a specimen of Pelagornis chilensis—an extinct bird that is the largest known, with a wingspan of more than 5 meters. Hendrik Poinar, a paleobiologist at McMaster University Hamilton, Canada, who has sequenced DNA from Chilean sloth material London, isn't worried about the possibility that museums might have to give back key specimens. "The key is that [objects] are accessible for scientific study," he says. Giraffatitan, for its part, likely stay put. Rather than press for its return, the Tanzanian government has said it would prefer support for excavating new fossils, training local paleontologists, and strengthening its museums. The Natural History Museum here host two museum staffers from Tanzania as visiting scholars this year, says Director-General Johannes Vogel. Meanwhile, Stoecker and Ina Heumann, the museum's staff historian, are working on expanded display documenting the dinosaur's history. Stoecker hopes to study the origins of the museum's mineral collection, much of which taken from Namibia during Germany's violent colonial reign there. Vogel says the collaboration with historians has paid off. "We want to encourage others to see what rich science there is all of this," he says. "There is more than just a natural science story to be told." *Correction, 28 March, 1:30 p.m.: This story has been updated to clarify the London Natural History Museum’s response to Science.

title: Nr. 77 | Holger Stoecker - WerkstattGeschichte
text: Holger Stoecker Ein afrikanischer Dinosaurier Berlin. Der Brachiosaurus brancai deutscher tansanischer Erinnerungsort Im Süden Kolonie Deutsch-Ostafrika führten 1906 afrikanische Arbeiter deutschen Minen-Prospektor gigantischen Knochenfossilien. Bald darauf, 1909 1913, unternahm Museum Naturkunde Berlin Expedition Tendaguru, weltweit erfolgreichste Ausgrabung Dinosaurierfossilien Zeiten erweisen sollte. Zu Funden zählte nahezu vollständige Skelett Brachiosaurus brancai, 1937 aufgestellt wurde seitdem weltweit größtes montiertes Dinosaurierskelett prominenteste Schauobjekt Museums ist. Galten Tendaguru-Fossilien Ende »Dritten Reiches« glanzvolle Belege effektive Allianz Wissenschaft Kolonialismus, verschwand danach kolonialer Erwerbskontext völlig musealen Erfolgsnarrativ. Mittlerweile Berliner Dinosaurier dabei, global umstrittenen Objekt werden: Seit Jahren mehren Tansania Stimmen, Rückgabe fordern. Vor Hintergrund Restitutionsforderungen diskutiert Artikel, inwiefern naturkundliche Objekte Brachiosaurus brancai Berliner Naturkundemuseum Erinnerungsorte verstanden können. An African Dinosaur Berlin: Brachiosaurus brancai as a German and Tanzanian Site of Memory In 1906, African workers led a German mining prospector to gigantic bone fossils the South of the colony of German East Africa. Thereupon, from 1909 to 1913, the Museum of Natural History Berlin undertook expedition to the Tendaguru hill, which proved to be the world’s most successful excavation of dinosaur fossils to date. Among the findings the almost complete skeleton of a Brachiosaurus brancai, which erected 1937 the Museum’s main hall. Since then it has been the world’s largest mounted dinosaur skeleton, and as such it has become the most prominent object of the museum. Until the end of the ‚Third Reich‘, the Tendaguru fossils had been regarded as shining evidences for the effective alliance between science and colonialism. Since then, however, its colonial acquisition context has disappeared almost completely from the museum’s own historical narrative. Meanwhile, the Berlin dinosaur is about to become a controversial object on a global scale. In recent years, demands for its restitution have been voiced Tanzania’s public debate. Against the backdrop of these demands, this article discusses to what extent natural objects such as the Brachiosaurus brancai the Berlin Museum of Natural History can be understood as ‚Sites of Memory‘. Kurz-Bio: Holger Stoecker Wissenschaftlicher Mitarbeiter Seminar Afrikawissenschaften Humboldt-Universität Berlin Mitglied BMBF geförderten Verbundprojekts „Dinosaurier Berlin“. E-Mail: holger.stoecker@rz.hu-berlin.de

title: The Bones of Reparation | Commune
text: For all its guilty memorials, Germany has never fully acknowledged its African genocide. Bones aren’t always political. For vertebrate animals they lie unseen, supporting the muscle, holding the cartilage, and serving as a vessel for marrow. Bones supply us with metaphors: “in one’s bones” alludes to one’s innermost feelings, while “to the bone” evokes a deep wound. Under the right conditions, some bones can even become fossils. The Museum of Natural History Berlin, Germany celebrates bones. Upon entering the museum one is presented with a spry graveyard of fossils, obeisance for German scientific expeditions. Towering over thirteen meters high, the reconstructed bones of the Brachiosaurus brancai stand erect at the museum’s foyer, while piles of fossils cower the shadows — fragments of the past revived by the rapt gaze of young visitors. Formerly known as the Brontosaurus, the Brachiosaurus brancai is ossified Jurassic treasure. Between these walls, one can view array of dinosaurs, the skeletons of birds of prey, the magnificent worlds of bees and wasps. Whether the collections are preserved formaldehyde or the aftermath of fleshless remains, children are invited to imagine elegiac giants and Lilliputian insects meandering emerald coppices. Yet reality, the museum is the resting place — though hopefully not the final one — for many African artifacts and remains. The Brachiosaurus brancai, as well as the Kentrosaurus aethiopicus (stegosaurus), Pterodactylus (pterodactyl), and certain fossilized corals and plants, were collected Tanzania between 1909 and 1913. Reading the museum plaques, a careful observer note brief references to the Tendaguru expedition, which led to the transfer of 225 tons of prehistoric fossils from Tanzania to Berlin — one consequence of German colonialism. At the Medical History Museum at the Charité Hospital Berlin, the bones are not as visible as they once were. In previous years, the skulls of the Herero and Nama people of present-day Namibia were catalogued and publicly displayed like the fragments of dinosaurs and primeval birds. Germany is still grappling with the legacy of colonial violence its former African colonies, recognizing the question of historical amends raised by this past. From 1884 to 1919, with the aid of administrators and scientists, the German Empire collected human skulls and primordial fossils from Deutsch-Südwestafrika (present-day Namibia) and Deutsch-Ostafrika (Burundi, Rwanda, and Tanzania). The skulls of Nama and Herero people were brought to Berlin and eventually housed at Charité. For the German scientists who appropriated them, these bones were enlisted to support their racist claims, a way of furnishing corporeal measurements to “objectively” verify their notions of white supremacy. These bones lie at the very heart of debates about German colonial history. Namibian and Tanzanian activists like Mnyaka Sururu Mboro, the co-founder of Berlin Postkolonial, have argued vehemently for the repatriation of these remains and for the involvement of African communities tracing the histories of these remains back to their origins. _____ Museums are sites of contradictions, telling ambiguous tales about the origins and trajectories of their objects. Museum signage does not tell visitors how displays were acquired, whether collectors paid for objects, what purpose these objects served, and how their meaning continues to evolve. Namibia and Tanzania were a living laboratory for the Imperial German Army, allowing for experiments with strategies of pacification and elimination that the Nazis would inherit. Here scientific language served as apologia for genocide, as colonizers observed and experimented on African prisoners and the deceased. In their photo essay, “Visual Archive of Colonialism: Germany and Namibia,” George Steinmetz and Julia Hell describe the occluded aspects of Germany’s colonial history, a history often unexamined by German laypeople. When Germans began to collect African objects, the human remains and premodern fossils were originally fragmented, scattered. Now they are part of a growing constellation of museum curation. These materials were not transplanted to Berlin by chance, nor did Africans willingly give them away. Mass death, colonialism, and white supremacy made this displacement possible. German scientists were agents of racial “science” directly linked to experimentation on African bodies the early twentieth century. Eugen Fischer, the director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute of Anthropology, involved the campaign to measure and catalogue the skulls and physical features of African prisoners Southwest Africa, which he hoped would prove the superiority of the Aryan race. He later served as a “racial hygienist” the Third Reich. The zoologist Leopard Schultze worked with dead bodies, acquiring approximately three hundred skulls of deceased African prisoners from Namibia’s concentration camps. These two men were part of a network of scientists, officials, and administrators who later promoted the racist ideology of the Nazi regime. Though the German government has yet to acknowledge these actions as genocide, the Imperial German Army committed massacres their Southwest African and East African colonies during the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries. Despite uprisings by the Herero, Nama, Maji Maji, and countless other groups, living humans, minerals, and bones were transplanted to Europe, making them inaccessible to most Namibians and Tanzanians. German colonialism Africa is underestimated at best, or, at worst, entirely unknown. The process of partitioning the African continent into European colonies and protectorates would come to be known as the “Scramble for Africa.” “Scramble” is a deceptive term, however, suggesting that the results were haphazardly produced, like the Lego structure of a five-year-old. In reality, the plan judiciously executed by thirteen European powers 1884 the city of Berlin. Carving a vast continent into pieces, these European governments deftly exercised varying forms of violence on Africans, their blades already sharpened by prior European “civilizing” and military commissions. From the late-nineteenth to the early-twentieth century, the Herero, the Nama, the Maji, and many other peoples excluded from German history textbooks were subjects of the German Empire. They were annexed to a European nation-state that transferred materials and goods, extracted gold and diamonds, and made alliances with the sovereign indigenous leaders. Apologists of German imperialism say that this period short-lived and less horrific than the plights of the British, French, or Spanish territories. Yet other voices understanding the core dimensions of imperialism would directly engage with Germany’s colonial aftermath and pave the way — as Hannah Arendt eloquently does The Origins of Totalitarianism — towards connecting German colonialism with its fascist history. German colonialism Southwest and East Africa — as played out Namibia and Tanzania — involved mineral extraction by imperialists, political resistance by African inhabitants, and the persecution of African dissidents by German administrators. While bones were shuffled and blood spilled, mineral resources were central to the colonial project. Like other European colonial powers Africa, Germans acquired diamonds, gold, and platinum. This made possible by a cast of characters who migrated from one colonial context to the next, often relying on enterprise and adventurism to enact their manifest destiny. For colonial Namibia, it Adolf Lüderitz who laid the groundwork for German settlement, while for colonial Tanzania, Carl Peters advanced the German imperial charter. Repatriation is central to undoing the damage of the past.” Prior to official German colonial rule, Lüderitz, a German merchant, sought to protect German financial and political interests Nama and Herero lands by investing the right to mine for gold and diamonds. By acquiring approximately one-third of Namibian land — which would later become Deutsch-Südwestafrika — he would solidify European satellite rule. With £770 gold coin and 260 rifles, Lüderitz, and eventually Germany, claimed jurisdiction over this land. The extent to which he paid for Nama and Herero land is contested, but we at least know he underpaid for territory worth far more the European mercantile system. German colonialists often laud Lüderitz for convincing the state to establish settlements and pursue gold mining. He did not live to see his colonial imagination fully realized, however. During expedition October 1886, he, his fellow settlers, and his boat, disappeared on the Orange River Southern Namibia. Lüderitz did not materially profit from the land that he purchased, but the German state did when it eventually mined gold and diamonds the colony. Twenty years after Lüderitz’s death, the Berlin-based German Colonial Society for Southwest Africa profited from the diamond mines Lüderitz himself unable to find. While different size, scope, and strategy, Deutsch-Ostafrika involved similar ambitions for exploration and resource extraction. These began with the aspirations of one man. The Society for German Colonization endowed colonial administrator Carl Peters with the power to promote the interests of the German East Africa Company Tanzania. As explorer and Imperial High Commissioner, his brutality towards the local population included sexual crimes against indigenous women. A 1896 New York Times article describes international scandal the German Reichstag: the socialist August Bebel and many others accused Carl Peters of barbary for murdering Black people colonial Tanzania. Over time, he discredited by his colleagues, dying the administrative ranks of Germany. However, his methods were celebrated two decades later by a rising star of fascism: Adolf Hitler. By the late-nineteenth century, Namibians and Tanzanians were open rebellion. In Namibia, the Khaua-Mbandjeru rebellion of 1896 one of the first of a wave of coordinated resistance movements by the indigenous population of the region. In Tanzania, Abushiri ibn Salim al-Harthi and his comrades initiated the Abushiri revolt of 1888. The Arab and Black militia employed a range of tactics, from political negotiation to guerilla fighting. None of these methods aligned with the German Empire’s desire for absolute rule. Unsurprisingly, the Germans executed Abushiri by public hanging. Even more gravely, the militia’s defeat ensured that Tanganyika land would go through multiple transfers — from the hands of the indigenous population to the German East Africa Company, and eventually to the German imperial state. The genocide of African people at the heart of the German colonial project and the murderous policies of the Nazi regime. Before the Nazis constructed concentration camps that murdered European Jews, Romani, Black Germans, disabled people, sexual minorities, and communists, they built concentration camps the rolling hills of Namibia for the Nama people. During the Maji Maji rebellion Tanzania, German colonial administrators starved out up to three hundred thousand people. Between 1904 and 1908, one hundred thousand Nama and Herero people were murdered during the German Imperial Army’s campaign. From the Caribbean and Latin America to Asia and Africa, people carry the colonial past their bones. Namibia and Tanzania are no exception. Nevertheless, the global fight being waged now for reparations is deepening our sense of history and outlining a pathway to long-overdue amends. _____ The debate on reparations is multifaceted, especially as its pendulum swings between the political and economic dimensions of the relationship between the formerly colonized and their former rulers. Amongst the African diaspora North America, Latin America, and the Caribbean, there are millions of direct descendants of slaves, indigenous people, and Europeans. The 2020 US presidential elections have re-enlivened the debate on reparations. Given the scale of historical tragedies, some argue that reparations must be global. Repatriation must be integral to reparations, especially cases outside the transatlantic slave trade and African diaspora. Early the twentieth century, Marcus Garvey catalyzed a pan-American international debate on reparations and the term has long been used by Black nationalists and residents of former slave colonies the Caribbean, Central America, and South America, as well as sub–Saharan African nation states. Reparation supporters have appealed to the League of Nations, the United Nations, the US Congress, the EU, and the British Parliament. The former president of Zaire (present-day Democratic Republic of Congo), Mobutu Sese Seko demanded the restitution of African arts before the UN General Assembly 1973. Seko convinced the African Museum of Art Belgium to return 144 artifacts. The Edo State government and the Benin royal court are demanding the creation of a museum Benin for materials that were stolen during the British expedition of 1897. As Godwin Obaseki, executive governor of Edo State, puts it, “These works are our ambassadors. They represent who we are.” Mass death is deemed “genocide” only when the victims are recognized as human. Beyond public recognition of this simple fact, how should perpetrators make amends? What happens when scientists are complicit murder? Nearly eighty years after the first punches were thrown, the 1985 UN Whitaker Report on Genocide listed the German massacre of the Hereros as genocide alongside other twentieth-century massacres, from the 1915 Armenian genocide to the 1919 Ukranian pogrom against Jews. The German government, however, only acknowledged the Imperial Army’s massacre of the Nama & Herero people as genocide 2015; they had previously classified the event as atrocity. As Joshua Kwesi Aikins, academic and political activist the Afro-German movement, told me interview: “It is up to this generation to demand that Germany recognize violence.” There are reasons for Germany’s initial amnesia about these crimes, however: admission would warrant compensation. Apologies for colonial violence are the first step, but they must extend into material, ongoing action. In Germany and beyond, the legacy of colonialism lives on the names of streets and institutions. Renaming is one way to strike at the roots of this violent past. Activists with the Initiative of Black People Germany have requested the renaming of streets the African quarter: Adolf Lüderitz, Gustav Nachtigal, and Carl Peters. As I walked through Wedding, a working-class multiethnic neighborhood northwestern Berlin, the tour guide reminded us that rather than erase history, residents want new street names that honor those whose lives were lost German colonial rule: Maji Maji Boulevard, Anna Mungunda Boulevard, Cornelius Frederiks Street, and Bell Square. The reparations project leads us back to the bones. At what point do we start to question what is on display, who is able to see it, how the gaze produces power? In the United States, the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act, effect since 1990, aims to return cultural objects and remains to their original Native American homes. Thousands of miles away, Australian museums holding Aborigines’ human remains have begun repatriating materials to the descendants of the colonized. Across the world, the effects of colonial science are undeniable, but often they remain invisible: many Germans have gone their entire lives without knowing which objects were taken from Namibia and Tanzania. Scientists and museums must face their past. The Tendaguru expedition not innocent exploration — it act of violence. The plight of remains has been central to the reparation and restitution debate for Africans living on the continent. While the German government has returned two dozen skulls, they may have thousands more. The initiative to return the skulls originated with the Herero and Nama people themselves, who wanted control over their collective memory. When pressed by descendants the Nama Traditional Leaders Association, the Stuttgart Museum Germany returned a bible and whip that once belonged to Chief Hendrik Witbooi — a nineteenth-century anticolonial leader Namibia. Herero and Nama representatives have sued the German government. The scale of materials that were collected and the terms of settlement suggest, however, that the negotiations are uneven affair. The key question is how to disrupt the uncomfortable, uneven relationship between former colonial powers and their former subjects. Countries like Germany possess the memories, profits, and materials of former colonies but present them only with patronizing relationships and perfunctory international aid programs. Reparations is colonial accountability with teeth. We should reckon not only with economic recompense, but with lost materials and silenced stories. Taking control of the narrative could be one path towards the liberation of the oppressed. Reparation can upend historical wrongs. When it works effectively, it acknowledges the humanity of the oppressed, allowing people to meet their economic and psychological needs. This means the ability to pay off inordinate debt fueled by lifetime bondage to colonial crimes, but it means returning artifacts that have been stolen. Repatriation is central to undoing the damage of the past. But there might be other avenues toward restitution, ones that more directly empower the formerly colonized. Several years before contributing to a report that calls for the restitution of African objects, Felwine Sarr argued his book Afrotopia: Africa has no one to catch up with. She must no longer run on the paths indicated to her, but walk briskly on the path she has chosen. Her status as the eldest daughter of humanity requires her to step out of the competition, this infantile age where nations are watching each other to know who has accumulated the most wealth, this frantic and irresponsible race that endangers the social and natural conditions of life. For Sarr and others, reparations would mean a radical reimagining of the African continent. Reparations would allow the dispossessed and the displaced to make demands on their own terms, through collective action, beyond the nation-state and its control over cultural legacy and collective memory. Reparations not take place the museum corridors of Berlin’s Natural History Museum or the display case at the Medical History Museum alone. Only a future beyond empire and capital can we properly lay our ancestral bones to rest.

title: Dekolonisierung in Berlin: Wem gehört der Dino? - taz.de
text: Dekolonisierung Berlin: Wem gehört Dino? Der Senat koloniale Vergangenheit Berlins aufarbeiten. Aktivisten fordern mehr Druck Museen, Sammlungen hinterfragen. Wie gehen kolonialen Vergangenheit Berlins um? Die Frage, viele Jahre Nachkommen Kolonialisierten paar linke HistorikerInnen interessierte, seit Zeit Konjunktur. In Bezirken gibt es, zumeist angestoßen zivilgesellschaftlichen AkteurInnen, inzwischen häufiger Debatten koloniale Straßennamen, Museen Sonderausstellungen, Führungen Workshops, Unis Thema „Koloniales Erbe“ vermehrt erforscht. Radikale DenkmalstürmerInnen versahen Wochen mehrere Standbilder Aufschrift „Decolonize Berlin“ – darunter Reichskanzler Bismarck, Initiator sogenannten Afrika-Konferenz. Und weiterhin Minderheit dürften, zeigt sich: Die Notwendigkeit „Entkolonialisierung“ Stadt Jahrzehnten Schweigens Verdrängens mehr mehr anerkannt. Auch Koalition: Im August 2019 beschloss Abgeordnetenhaus Überschrift „Berlin übernimmt Verantwortung koloniale Vergangenheit“, Senat solle gesamtstädtisches Aufarbeitungs- Erinnerungskonzept entwickeln. Knapp Jahr später Senat – Verspätung – ersten Zwischenbericht vorgelegt. Neben Bekenntnis bereits Beschlossenem – etwa Entwicklung zentralen Gedenkstätte Opfer Kolonialismus – enthält Bericht Neuigkeiten. So richtet Senat Koordinierungsstelle ein, Erstellung Umsetzung Dekolonisierungskonzepts begleiten Teilhabe Zivilgesellschaft gewährleisten soll. Träger Bündnis Decolonize Berlin, Zusammenschluss zehn postkolonialen antirassistischen Intiatiativen, darunter Berlin Postkolonial, AfricAvenir Initiative Schwarzer Menschen Deutschland (ISD). Budget: 250.000 Euro pro Jahr. Die Koordinierungsstelle Workshops organisieren, wissenschaftliche Gutachten Auftrag geben, Online-Partizipationsformen entwickeln, Akteure vernetzen. Am 15. 16. September Betahaus zweitätige „Zukunftskonferenz“ veranstalten. Räume Das Projekt, Ende 2024 läuft, Sitz Wilhelmstraße 92 – historischen Ort „Afrika-Konferenz“ 1884/85. Kartierung Ein Bestandteil „transnationale Kartierung“ rund 1.000 Orten Berlin Städten Deutschland sowie ehemaligen Kolonien. Eingebettet „Touren“ sollen Lebensgeschichten, Kolonisierten, sowie Wege Objekten „human remains“ Kolonien hierher dargestellt werden. Ausstellungen Das Projekt Jahr Ausstellung organisieren Kooperation Bezirksmuseen: Es beginnt 2021 Treptow-Köpenick ersten deutschen Kolonialausstellung, 2022 folgt Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg Thema Kolonial-Migration Berlin. Es gibt zudem Beratung Museen, kritisch eigenen (Sammlungs-)Geschichte auseinander setzen wollen. Interventionen Ein jährliches Festival (das erste 15.11. Wilhelmstr. 92) künstlerische Interventionen sollen Kolonialgeschichte Stadtraum sichtbar machen. Thinktanks sollen nachdenken geplanten zentralen Erinnerungsort. Termine 21. August: „Dekoloniales Flanieren M-Straße“. Start 17 Uhr U-Bahnhof M-Straße. 23. August: 11-17 Uhr: „Dekonstruktion kolonialer Geschichten Technikmuseum“. Eine umstrittene Installation Versklavungshandel künstlerischen Performance abgebaut. Liveübertragung Hausvogteiplatz Rahmen 7. M-Straßen-Umbenennungsfestes. Dieses startet 13 Uhr Demo Lustgarten, gegenüber Humboldt-Forums. (sum) Keine eigene Uni-Forschungsstelle Kolonialismus Auch geben soll, steht Zwischenbericht: eigene „Forschungsstelle Kolonialismus“ hiesigen Uni – Hamburg seit 2014 gibt. Der Senat erachte „zielführend“, heißt es, bereits Vielzahl Forschungsprojekten Thema gebe. Zudem fehlten aktuell finanziellen Mittel. Christian Kopp, Historiker Aktivist Gruppe Berlin Postkolonial, findet: „Grundsätzlich mittelfristig“ wäre Forschungsstelle schon wünschen. Allerdings sei positiv, Senat „zuerst enge Zusammenarbeit afrodiasporischen postkolonialen Initiativen“ gesucht deren erinnerungskulturelle Aktivitäten fördere. Dies geschieht fünfjährigen Kulturprojekt „Dekoloniale Erinnerungskultur Stadt“, Berlin Postkolonial, Each One Teach One ISD zusammen Stadtmuseum durchführen werden. Das Projekt, Land 2024 2 Millionen Euro finanziert, Dienstag Programm vorgestellt (siehe Kasten). Als Schwachpunkt Senatsberichts erweist Bereich Provinienzforschung Museen, sprich: Erforschung Herkunft Bestände. An Thema Debatte koloniale Erbe Jahren zuerst entzündet – Stichwort Humboldt Forum rekonstruierten Berliner Schloss. Der Senat betont, Land Institutionen Stiftung Preußischer Kulturbesitz Stiftung Humboldt Forum „keinen eingeschränkten inhaltlichen Einfluss“. Man setze Rahmen Möglichen „für kritische Auseinandersetzung“ Sammlungen ein. Mehr Geld Provinienzforschung nötig Für kulturpolitischen Sprecher Grünen-Fraktion, Daniel Wesener, „weitgehend indifferente Haltung Landes Berlin musealen Feld“ „eigentliche Versäumnis“. Er fordert Öffnung Depots Archive Sammlungen Institutionen sowie schnelle Digitalisierung Objekte, „bei denen Zusammenhang Kolonialvergangenheit nahe liegt“ – Herkunftsländer überhaupt erfahren, hiesigen Museen lagert – zurückfordern könnten. Dafür müsse Politik Geld Verfügung stellen, gibt zu. Bislang geschieht begrenzt, wichtige erste Pilotprojekte, etwa menschlichen Überresten, wurden private Gerda-Henkel-Stiftung finanziert. Wesener verspricht: „Als Grüne dafür einsetzen, Berlin notwendige finanzielle Vorsorge trifft.“ Auch gegenüber Museen eigener Hand zeigt Senat bislang wenig fordernd. Zwar heißt es, Land Berlin bekenne „ersten Eckpunkten Umgang Sammlungsgut kolonialen Kontexten“ Kultusministerkonferenz, „proaktiver Provenienzforschung ggf. Restitutionen“ verpflichtet. Der Bericht bestätigt auch, Landesmuseen Museum Naturkunde (MfN), Botanische Museum, Medizinhistorische sowie Brücke-Museum Sammlungsbestände ehemaligen Kolonien verfügen – MfN sogar „erheblichen Anteil“. Dennoch scheint Thema Letzterem Priorität haben. Laut Bericht untersucht Naturkundemuseum Erwerbungsgeschichte „prominenten Objekten“. Im Folgesatz jedoch einzigen Objekt Rede: „Bislang betrifft Dinosaurierer Giraffatitan (Brachiosaurus) brancai“. Das angeblich weltgrößte rekonstruierte Dino-Skelett Hauptattraktionen Naturkundemuseums. Es wurde, viele Ausstellungstücke Dinosaurier-Saal, großen Expedition 1909–1913 Berg Tendaguru damaligen Kolonie „Deutsch-Südost“, heutigen Tansania, ausgegraben. Von gibt inzwischen vermehrt Forderungen WissenschaftlerInnen, Museumsleuten PolitikerInnen Rückgabe Knochen. Tansania angeblich Interesse Restitution Im Senatsbericht heißt knapp, bislang „offiziellen Restitutionsanfragen“ gebe. Auch Museumsdirektor Johannes Vogel betont taz-Nachfrage. Tansanias Außenminister Mai 2018 anlässlich Besuchs deutschen Außenministers sogar betont, „dass Interesse Rückforderung gibt“, sagt Vogel. Wesener gibt bedenken, Regierungen ehemaliger Kolonien womöglich wegen Abhängigkeit Entwicklungshilfe politischen Gründen „die Interessen Nachkommen ehemals Kolonisierten bedingt vertreten“. Mnyaka Sururu Mboro Berlin Postkolonial argumentiert, genüge nicht, offizielle Forderungen Regierungen warten. Museen MfN müssten aktiv Herkunftsgesellschaften Rückgabe Objekten kolonialen Kontexten anbieten. „Denn Versöhnung gelingen, Einsicht Unrecht erkennen Wille, Wiedergutmachung leisten“, sagt Mboro. „Es braucht Zeichen setzende Rückgabeangebote, Beispiel Dinosaurier-Überresten Tansania.“ Wesener findet, MfN solle „die koloniale Geschichte Teilen Sammlung Thema machen, anstatt ständig abzuwiegeln“. Das geschehe längst, erwidert Museumsdirektor Vogel. Seit Jahren arbeite Wissenschaftlern Tansania zusammen. Auch verweist Senatsbericht erwähnte Forschungsprojekt Brachiosaurus, 2018 Buchveröffentlichung „Dinosaurierfragmente“ abgeschlossen wurde. „Wir Beschriftungen Sauriersaal entsprechend überarbeitet“, sagt er, schon heute BesucherInnen Grabungsarbeiten Bild machen. „Dinosaurierjagd Tendaguru“ Das allerdings halbe Wahrheit. Zwar gibt Sauriersaal seit 2007 Schaukasten Grabungsarbeiten. Das Diorama Überschrift „Dinosauerierjagd Tendaguru“ Stil Abenteuergeschichte gehalten, Hinweise kolonialen Kontext Expedition sucht vergebens. Gleiches gilt übrigen Beschriftungen, zwei Jahre Veröffentlichung Forschungsberichts unverändert sind. Andere Landesmuseen scheinen ambitionierter sein. Das Botanische Museum etwa plant, kolonialen Bezüge Sammlung neuen Dauerausstellung ab 2023 „zeitgemäß“ vermitteln. Auch Technikmuseum „scheint glaubhaft langen Weg Dekolonisierung begeben haben“, loben Kopp Mboro. Insgesamt beiden Aktivisten Zwischenbericht Senats recht zufrieden: Die Politik sei puncto Aufarbeitung guten Weg. Zumindest Ende genügend Geld fließe, all aufgelisteten Projekte verwirklichen. Man Fall Eindruck, Senat ernsthaft Thema interessiert sei „und Vorreiterrolle Deutschland international einnehmen möchte“.

title: Dinosaurs of Tendaguru and similar topics | Frankensaurus.com
text: Topics similar to or like Dinosaurs of Tendaguru The Tendaguru Formation, or Tendaguru Beds are a highly fossiliferous formation and Lagerstätte southeastern Tanzania. The formation represents the oldest sedimentary unit of the Mandawa Basin, overlying Neoproterozoic basement, separating by a long hiatus and unconformity. Wikipedia Genus of herbivorous sauropod dinosaur from the Late Jurassic of Tanzania. In 1911, German geologist Wilhelm Bornhardt at Nambango German East Africa discovered two sauropod vertebrae, fifteen kilometers (nine miles) southeast of Tendaguru Hill. Wikipedia Extinct genus of carcharodontosaurid theropod dinosaur known from the Jurassic of Tendaguru, southeastern Tanzania. Known from the holotype specimen MB R 1938, isolated middle caudal vertebra. Wikipedia Large herbivorous sauropod dinosaur from the Late Jurassic Tendaguru Formation of Tanzania, Africa, 155-145 million years ago. During the German expeditions to the Tendaguru German East Africa between 1909 and 1912, paleontologist Werner Janensch supervised the excavation of a sauropod tail at "Site G". Wikipedia Coastal town located at the far end of Lindi Bay, on the Indian Ocean southeastern Tanzania. 450 kilometers south of Dar Salaam and 105 kilometers north of Mtwara, the southernmost coastal town Tanzania, and gives its name to the surrounding Lindi Region, one of the most sparsely populated areas of the country. Wikipedia One of the five districts of the Lindi Region of Tanzania. Bordered to the north by the Kilwa District, to the south by the Mtwara Region, to the west by the Nachingwea District, and to the east by the Indian Ocean and the municipality of Lindi. Wikipedia District the Lindi Region of Tanzania. Bordered to the north by the Ruangwa District, to the east by the Lindi Rural District, to the south-east by the Mtwara Region, and to the south-west by the Ruvuma Region. Wikipedia Planned liquefied natural gas processing plant Tanzania. The plant would be located on approximately 2071.705 ha Likong'o Village the town of Lindi on the Indian Ocean coast, approximately 460 km, by road, south of Dar Salaam. Wikipedia One of the five districts of the Lindi Region of Tanzania. Bordered to the north by the Pwani Region, to the east by the Kilwa District, to the south by the Ruangwa District and to the west by the Morogoro Region. Wikipedia One of the five districts of the Lindi Region of Tanzania. Bordered to the north by the Pwani Region, to the east by the Indian Ocean, to the south by the Lindi Rural District and to the west by the Liwale District. Wikipedia Genus of theropod dinosaur from the Late Jurassic period of what is now Tanzania. Known only from fossil teeth discovered sometime between 1909 and 1912, during expedition to the Tendaguru Formation by the Natural History Museum of Berlin. Wikipedia Large open pit mine located the southern part of Tanzania Lindi Region. Manyoni represents one of the largest uranium reserves Tanzania having estimated reserves of 182.1 million tonnes of ore grading 0.025% uranium. Wikipedia Genus of ceratosaurian theropod dinosaur that lived approximately 154 to 150 million years ago during the later part of the Jurassic Period what is now Tanzania Africa. Medium-sized but lightly built member of the group that could grow up to 6.2 m long. Wikipedia Genus of sauropod dinosaur that lived during the late Jurassic Period (Kimmeridgian–Tithonian stages). Originally named as African species of Brachiosaurus , but this has since been changed. Wikipedia List of stratigraphic units dinosaur trace fossils have been recovered from. Clade which includes the descendant taxon Aves , this article covers only stratigraphic units containing Mesozoic forms. Wikipedia Sentences Sentences forDinosaurs of Tendaguru - The 1998, illustrated book Swahili, whose title translates as Dinosaurs of Tendaguru, published for young readers East Africa.Tendaguru Formation-Wikipedia - Dinosaurs of Tendaguru (original title: Dinosaria wa Tendaguru) is a story for young readers that combines both fiction and natural history, focussing on the discovery and subsequent excavations of dinosaur fossils at Tendaguru hill Lindi Region of South Eastern Tanzania.Tanzanian literature-Wikipedia This create email alert. title: User:Munfarid1 - Meta - Meta-Wiki - Wikimedia
text: User:Munfarid1 Hello and welcome on my user page, having lived and worked a German organization for cultural exchange the Middle East, North and East Africa for many years, I especially interested writing or contributing to articles about art and artists these regions. I write mainly German and English, but sometimes edit French or Spanish, too. Of course, any serious contribution to my articles is welcome. Munfarid1 (talk) 12:54, 25 April 2019 (UTC)Munfarid1 |User language| |de-N||Dieser Benutzer spricht Deutsch Muttersprache.| |en-5||This user has professional knowledge of English.| |fr-4||Cet utilisateur dispose de connaissances proches de la langue maternelle en français.| |es-4||Esta persona tiene un conocimiento casi nativo del español.| My latest articles, or major updates of articles, reflecting my current interests: Sudan: Richard Buchta, Photography of Sudan, Music of Sudan, Cinema of Sudan, Sudanese literature, Gadalla Gubara, Aswat Almadina, Nancy Agag, Sharhabil Ahmed, Igd al-Jallad, Rasha, Talking about Trees, Stella Gaitano, Ibrahim el-Salahi, Abdelaziz Baraka Sakin, Muhammad al-Fayturi, Abdel Karim Karouma, Mohammed al Amin, Mahmoud Abdulaziz, Hammour Ziada, Sabah Sanhouri, Khalid Albaih, Ibrahim al Kashif, Amir Taj el-Sir Morocco: Abdallah Zrika Other African countries: Report on the restitution of African cultural heritage, National Museum of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Dinosaurs of Tendaguru, Hans Cory, Syria: Mouneer Al-Shaarani, Kinan Azmeh, Hewar, Dima Orsho, Higher Institute of Dramatic Arts (Damascus), Syrian National Orchestra for Arabic Music, Damascus Opera House, Syrian National Symphony Orchestra Myanmar: National Museum of Myanmar (Yangon), National Museum of Myanmar (Naypyidaw), Philip Adolphe Klier, Max Henry Ferrars Germany: Manfred Leuchter Cinema: Cairo Station Other topics: Robert Lachmann 0.00024% This user has created 15 of the 6,208,611 articles on the English language Wikipedia. |This is a Wikimedia global user page.| If you find this page on any site other than a Wikimedia project, you are viewing a mirror site. Be aware that the page may be outdated, and that user whom this page is about may have no personal affiliation with the site. The original page is located at https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/User:Munfarid1.

title: Wem gehört der Dino? Teil 3 - In der Knochenkammer
text: Reste Sauriern, Mammuts Mastodonten Berliner Naturkundemuseum aufbewahrt. (picture alliance / dpa / Rainer Jensen) In Knochenkammer Naturkundemuseums liegen allein mehr 10.000 Fossilien Tansania. Für Präparator Jobgarantie Rente. Doch fühlt Erica an, inmitten all Knochen Heimat arbeiten? "Hier paar Bilder, vermutlich 100 Jahre alt. Hier sieht man, damals Sachen Boden rausgeholt haben", sagt Michele Kaiser zeigt paar alte Schwarz-Weiß Fotos berühmten Tendaguru-Expedition, Schrank gegenüber Kellerregale kleben: "Und wirklich getragen, Schiffe verladen ab Deutschland." Brechen Kleben Wir sogenannten Knochenkammer Naturkundemuseums, kleinen Wirbeltieren Mammut Dinosaurier Fossilien liegen – davon allein mehr 10.000 Tansania. "Das oben Reusen, Kisten voll – Tendaguru, gerade bearbeite. Man wirklich sagen, immer Arbeit da. Selbst ich, 40 Jahre arbeiten würde, nie schaffen, fertig präparieren, liegt." In Knochenkammer Naturkundemuseums lagern Reusen Fossilien einhundert Jahre alten Tendaguru-Expedition. (Eberhard Schade) Für Präparator: Jobgarantie Rente. "Deswegen auseinanderbrechen, quasi große Thema: Auseinanderbrechen, gucken, drinnen ist, Ende zusammenkleben." Wir oben, Innenhof riesigen Museumskomplexes. Abteilung Paläontologische Präparation. Überall Mikroskope, Bohrer Sandstrahlgeräte. Michele Kaisers Arbeitsplatz. Vor Dornfortsatz Dino-Wirbels. Spröder, weicher Knochen. "Hier arbeite schon Monat dran vermutlich weit zwei – Knochen. Und vorstellt, ganzen Dinosaurier oben stehen hat, Monate Jahre, daran arbeitet. Vor Knochen ergänzen muss, Dinosaurier komplett gefunden hat. Es wirklich Jahre." Und genau sollen ja Erica Frank lernen. "Denn holt ja einfach Knochen Boden fertig, fängt ja schon Präparation an, Monate dauert. Es hört Restauration auf. Wenn Klima vorstellt, warm ist, schauen: Kleber binden Wärme schneller ab. Das Handling haben. Feuchtigkeit, Wärme, Kälte nachts. Die Lagerung wichtig. Und Knochen Jahre liegen, immer drübergucken. Es riesiger Apparat, beachten hat." Echte Handarbeit Knochen Erica, ja Paläontologie gefreut hatte, super glücklich, sagt sie, paar Wochen Teil Prozesses können: "Denn Saurier steht ja schon Halle, weiß ich, einzelnen Knochen vorher präpariert wurden. Wie einzelne gereinigt wird, Sedimente weggefräst werden. Wie lange Prozess dauert dabei konzentrieren muss, Details zerstören. Alles wissenschaftlich professionell." Brechen Kleben: Arbeit Knochen Paläontologie. (Eberhard Schade) Zwei Wochen Excel-Tabelle, Hinterhersein irgendwelchen Fristen Parasitenausstellung. Sondern "hands on" – echte Handarbeit Dinoknochen. Und fühlt inmitten all Knochen Heimat? "Die ganze Debatte Rückgabe Dinosaurier ja Tansania alt. Diejenigen, Knochen ausgebuddelt verschifft haben, wussten ja nicht, bedeutender Fund ist. Jetzt aber, inmitten Diskussion, sagen plötzlich viele: Das wäre toll, Skelett hätten, hier, Daressalam ausstellen könnten." Sie froh, entscheiden müssen. "Ich glaube, Debatte ist, Level stattfinden sollte. Ich wirklich sagen entscheiden, besser Tansania sollte. Auch Objekten gar weiß, warum sind." Ericas Chef Tansania Knochen zurück Ericas Chef Daressalam dagegen, Audax Mabulla, gar großartig debattieren. Er Knochen zurück das: "Die Deutschen sollten Bedeutung Rückgabe Kulturgüter sehen. Und nur, wichtig ist, zurückzugeben, Tansania nötigen Mitteln auszustatten, fachgerecht lagern, präparieren auszustellen. Und heißt auch, Bemühungen unterstützen. Ich glaube, intelligente Deutsche unterschreibt deshalb möglich ist." Michele Kaiser Gespräch Frank Arbeitsplatz Paläontologie. (Eberhard Schade) Damit Erica Knochen immer bald genauso gut deutscher Kollege Michele Kaiser bearbeiten präparieren kann, Übung weicheren Gesteinsblock gegeben, einzelne Muschelrücken herausragen. Erica legt frei. Sitzt weißen Kittel Schutzbrille Mikroskop gebeugt fräst geschickt Steinüberstände ab. Danach braucht Block kurz sandstrahlen - schöne, glatte Oberfläche. Michele Kaiser beeindruckt. "Für Anfänger wirklich wirklich super. Das wirklich gut hinbekommen. Für Einblick super, reicht eigentlich." Alle Beiträge Reihe Überblick. (picture alliance / Ulrich Baumgarten) Den Muschelblock darf Erica Hause, Tansania, nehmen. Die Dinoknochen bleiben natürlich hier. Noch. Wir vergessen, verletzlich Mensch Hitze ist, warnt Eckart Hirschhausen Blick jüngste Hitzewelle. Der Arzt Kabarettist empfiehlt, möglichen Ansatzpunkten starten, Erderwärmung begrenzen.Mehr Das Privileg richtigen Hautfarbe: Alexis Schaitkin erzählt hellsichtigen Kriminalroman "Saint X" ungeklärten Tod jungen weißen Amerikanerin Karibikinsel Ignoranz bessergestellten Welt.Mehr Frédéric Beigbeder zeigt boshafter Kritiker eigenen Milieus: Während Gelbwesten Paris ziehen, denkt Romanheld scheinheilige Weltverbesserer, soziale Ungerechtigkeit, eigene Sexleben nächsten Drogenrausch nach.Mehr
